speaker: James
text: The energy revolution is upon us, but not for the reasons most people assume. Our latest piece argues it's got nothing to do with climate change, and precious little with national security. It's simply about economics.

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. Nothing to do with climate change? That's quite a statement, even for us. Especially when we've published pieces like 'Dealing With The Consequences Of Climate Change Inaction'.

speaker: James
text: A statement based on our previous admission: we've missed the boat. Global average temperatures will rise. Lobbying national governments won't stop it. Both sides of the climate debate can agree nothing material will be done in time. So, it ceases to be the *driver* for a new energy source.

speaker: Elena
text: But the US military is deeply concerned, you mention it yourself. That suggests national security *is* a factor, at least for some very powerful players.

speaker: James
text: Yes, they're concerned about global security. But the article makes it clear: national security hasn't driven adoption. Too many incumbents in that sector unwilling to share the tax pot. No, the main driver is economic. Pure and simple.

speaker: Elena
text: So, solar, which has historically been prohibitively expensive, is now... too cheap? That's quite a leap. It's usually a story about subsidies making it viable.

speaker: James
text: Not a leap at all. It's about marginal cost. Think about how electricity markets work, the 'merit order'. Conventional plants – coal, gas, old nuclear – they have base load. They're cheap to run continuously, but costly to switch off.

speaker: Elena
text: Right, and the spot price is set by the most expensive generator online at any given moment. Usually a gas peaker, or even diesel, during peak demand.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. And where do conventional power stations make the bulk of their profit? During those daily peaks. When demand is highest, and the spot price is inflated by those expensive flexible plants.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay. So where does solar fit into this?

speaker: James
text: Solar has no fuel costs. Very low maintenance. Its marginal cost is effectively zero. And when does solar produce its peak output?

speaker: Elena
text: During the day. When demand surges. Oh.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. Solar can always undercut conventional power during peak daylight hours. It eats into their most profitable window.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... actually devastating for them.

speaker: James
text: It is. Deutsche Bank analysts found solar PV was cutting peak electricity prices by up to 40% in Germany. Utilities there found it 'intolerable'.

speaker: Elena
text: Forty percent? Wait, when did that happen?

speaker: James
text: Years ago. March 2012, the article states. One quarter of Germany's gas-fired capacity may have closed due to surging solar and wind. Enel in Italy saw a one-third slump in earnings from their generation division.

speaker: Elena
text: But what about intermittency? The grid needs reliability. You can't just switch off everything when the sun sets or the wind drops.

speaker: James
text: True, but the point is solar takes the top off the profit curve for conventional plants. It makes their peak-time operation uneconomic. And as we discussed in 'The renewables and battery revolution', battery storage is improving dramatically.

speaker: Elena
text: Still, it sounds like a nightmare for utilities. Having to keep expensive backup capacity online, but losing the revenue to pay for it.

speaker: James
text: It gets worse for them. Consider the retail price versus wholesale price problem. Households put solar on their roofs...

speaker: Elena
text: And generate their own daytime power. Reducing their bill from the utility.

speaker: James
text: Which means the cost of maintaining the grid, the balancing services – all those fixed costs – get spread across a smaller base of remaining retail customers. So, their prices go up.

speaker: Elena
text: And higher retail prices incentivise *more* people to switch to solar. That's a death spiral, isn't it?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. The article calls it a quandary for utilities because it eats into their higher profit business. No amount of political influence can change the physics of a lower marginal cost.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the losers are... anyone involved in conventional power. GE, for their generators. Coal and gas companies. Utilities themselves.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. It takes 3-7 years to plan and build a conventional power station. How much sense does it make to invest in something that will very likely be more expensive than solar by the time it comes online, and certainly within a few years of operation?

speaker: Elena
text: No, that's completely wrong, and I'll tell you why. Seven years is a long time. Innovation cycles are shorter. They'll adapt. They have to.

speaker: James
text: But the fundamental economic advantage of zero fuel cost remains. You can innovate all you like, but you still have to buy coal, or gas. Solar's raw material is sand. Improved manufacturing means even cheaper, more efficient panels.

speaker: Elena
text: I suppose... the cost curve for solar just keeps dropping, doesn't it?

speaker: James
text: It does. Even without subsidies, capacity is being built. Spain, for instance.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, fine. I'll give you that. The economics are brutal. But what about oil? How does solar impact the oil majors directly?

speaker: James
text: Electric vehicles. They're perfect companions for solar. Cars are parked most of the day. They can recharge during peak solar hours, making them incredibly cheap to run.

speaker: Elena
text: Yes, but we're still seeing conventional cars expand rapidly in developing countries. The transition won't be overnight.

speaker: James
text: No, the article says it's a ten-year revolution. Incumbents will fight back, use their political influence. But like a game of musical chairs, the music will stop.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the question is where you want to be left standing, as a shareholder. Or a country, for that matter. This ties back to what we discussed about 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power' – resource control is shifting.

speaker: James
text: Absolutely. It's a structural shift, not a temporary blip. The underlying economics are irrefutable.

speaker: Elena
text: I still worry about the speed. What happens to the communities built around coal mines, gas fields? The jobs lost in traditional power generation? This isn't just about share prices; it's about livelihoods.

speaker: James
text: That's a valid concern, Elena. Historical precedents abound, from the Luddites to the decline of shipbuilding. Economic revolutions always create losers, even if the overall benefit is great. But the evidence suggests resisting the inevitable only prolongs the pain.

speaker: Elena
text: So, we're not just 'missing the boat' on climate change, but about to capsize it for a whole sector of the economy. Cheery.

speaker: James
text: Unflinching, as ever. It's about understanding the forces at play. And solar's low marginal cost is a force of nature, in its own way.
